--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
<snip>

> >I've just released a small software package for
> free download.  It 
> >contains a simplified physics model of a sailboat,
> and a means of 
> >controlling it.  There is a goal, to sail around a
<snip>

> Sounds interesting. What was the driving force
> behind creating a sailing 
> simulation? For some time now I have been thinking

I like vehicles, and optimization problems involving
continous functions and curving paths.  In addition
the sailboat has this strange quirk that there is a
range of forbidden directions, where the boat cannot
sustain a velocity vector.  Also, the controller has
to choose a path to follow, then set both the rudder
and sails.  (although with a NN this is not explicit)
There is a range of rudder/sail combos that will
follow a given path, but one combo will be fastest.

<snip>

> >It's written in C.  You can get it from 
> >http://annevolve.sourceforge.net.
> >
> I haven't tried using NEAT yet. Maybe if no-one else
> volunteers 
> beforehand then I'll try and apply it to your
> environment over the weekend.

It's OK if more than one person tries.  They won't
necessarily obtain the exact same results.  Using NEAT
is not fully automatic, some manual "shifting" is
required. :)

m
